result.execSummary:
The defendant Derek T. ODonnell was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Manufacture/Deliver Heroin (<3g), a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1)(d)1.
  • Bail Jumping-Felony, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  

A copy of the police report has been faxed to the probation office.

Clerk Marisa.
Case Called: 1:35 pm 
INCLUDES 13CF1007, 13CM2338, 13CM2340, 14CF50, 14CF293, 14CF341, 14CF505, 14CM145, AND 13TR8247. 
State appears by ADA Chad Minder; Deft appears in person, in custody with Atty Amanda Ley. VRCW. 
COURT notes PSI and sentencing memorandum and questions parties regarding review of reports. Atty Ley notes no additions or corrections to reports. State notes corrections to restitution in PSI as follows: $52.07 to 2510 in 13CF1007, $24.00 to Best Buy in 14CF293, and $201.50 to Downtown Pawn in 13CF1007. 
Argument. Deft makes statement. 
COURT makes findings. 

COURT ORDERS: In 13CF1007: Ct. 2 (Theft)>>SWH for 2 years probation. 
                           : In 14CF293: Ct. 1 (Felony BJ)>>SWH for 3 years probation. 
                                                 : Ct. 3 (Retail Theft/PTAC)>>SWH for 2 years probation. 
                                                 : Ct. 6 (Retail Theft)>>SWH for 2 years probation. 
                            : In 14CF341: Ct. 1 (Felony BJ)>>SWH for 3 years probation. 
                            : In 14CF505: Ct. 1 (Manufacture/Deliver Heroin)>8 years imprisonment - 3 years IC and 5 years ES - imposed and STAYED for 5 years probation. 
                                                  : Ct. 2 (Felony BJ)>>SWH for 3 years probation. 

COURT ORDERS as CONDITIONS of Probation in all>>assessment/treatment/counseling as deemed appropriate by the dept; absolute sobriety from drugs and alcohol except for prescriptions taken as prescribed and with prior agent authorization; no contact with anyone using, possessing, or purchasing controlled substances or drug parapheranalia; maintain fulltime employment/schooling/combination of the 2 or if not, perform 10 hours community service per week; payment of court costs. 
COURT ORDERS as CONDITION of Probation in 13CF1007: Payment of restitution of $52.07 to 2510 Restaurant, $477 to D.K, $1180 to KZ, and $201.50 to Downtown Pawn to be paid at a rate of at least $100 per month. 
COURT ORDERS as CONDITION of Probation in 14CF293: Payment of restitution of $24 to Best Buy, and $97.42 to Wal-Mart to be paid at a rate of at least $25 per month until paid in full. 
COURT ORDERS as CONDITION of Probation in 14CF341: 1 years MCJ with huber for work/school/treatment if def qualifies under jail criteria. 
COURT ORDERS as CONDITION of Probation in 14CF505: DNA sample and surcharge. 

COURT finds def is entitled to 306 days credit in each file if revoked. 
COURT finds the def eligible for CIP and SAP. 

COURT ORDERS PSI and Sentencing Memorandum be sealed. 
Counsel to retain copies of PSI and maintain their confidentiality.
